para.sentence: The inverse Jacobian elliptic functions can be defined in an analogous manner to the inverse trigonometric functions (§4.23).

With real variables, the solutions of the equations \operatorname{sn}\left(\xi,k\right)=x, if -1\leq x\leq 1, \operatorname{cn}\left(\eta,k\right)=x, if -1\leq x\leq 1, \operatorname{dn}\left(\zeta,k\right)=x, if k^{\prime}\leq x\leq 1, are denoted respectively by \xi=\operatorname{arcsn}\left(x,k\right),\eta=\operatorname{arccn}\left(x,k\right),\zeta=\operatorname{arcdn}\left(x,k\right).

Each of these inverse functions is multivalued. The principal values satisfy -K\leq\operatorname{arcsn}\left(x,k\right)\leq K, , 0\leq\operatorname{arccn}\left(x,k\right)\leq 2K, , 0\leq\operatorname{arcdn}\left(x,k\right)\leq K, and unless stated otherwise it is assumed that the inverse functions assume their principal values.

The general solutions of (22.15.1), (22.15.2), (22.15.3) are, respectively, \xi=(-1)^{m}\operatorname{arcsn}\left(x,k\right)+2mK, , \eta=\pm\operatorname{arccn}\left(x,k\right)+4mK, , \zeta=\pm\operatorname{arcdn}\left(x,k\right)+2mK, where m\in\mathbb{Z}.

Equations (22.15.1) and (22.15.4), for \operatorname{arcsn}\left(x,k\right) , are equivalent to (22.15.12) and also to x=\int_{0}^{\operatorname{sn}\left(x,k\right)}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt{(1-t^{2 })(1-k^{2}t^{2})}}, if -1\leq x\leq 1, 0\leq k\leq 1.
Similarly with (22.15.13)–(22.15.23) and the other eleven Jacobian elliptic functions.

\operatorname{arcsn}\left(x,k\right)=\int_{0}^{x}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt{(1-t ^{2})(1-k^{2}t^{2})}}, if -1\leq x\leq 1, \operatorname{arccn}\left(x,k\right)=\int_{x}^{1}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt{(1-t ^{2})({k^{\prime}}^{2}+k^{2}t^{2})}}, if -1\leq x\leq 1, \operatorname{arcdn}\left(x,k\right)=\int_{x}^{1}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt{(1-t ^{2})(t^{2}-{k^{\prime}}^{2})}}, if k^{\prime}\leq x\leq 1 .

\operatorname{arccd}\left(x,k\right)=\int_{x}^{1}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt{(1-t ^{2})(1-k^{2}t^{2})}}, if -1\leq x\leq 1, \operatorname{arcsd}\left(x,k\right)=\int_{0}^{x}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt{(1-{ k^{\prime}}^{2}t^{2})(1+k^{2}t^{2})}}, if -1/k^{\prime}\leq x\leq 1/k^{\prime}, \operatorname{arcnd}\left(x,k\right)=\int_{1}^{x}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt{(t^{ 2}-1)(1-{k^{\prime}}^{2}t^{2})}}, if 1\leq x\leq 1/k^{\prime}, \operatorname{arcdc}\left(x,k\right)=\int_{1}^{x}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt{(t^{ 2}-1)(t^{2}-k^{2})}}, if 1\leq x<\infty, \operatorname{arcnc}\left(x,k\right)=\int_{1}^{x}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt{(t^{ 2}-1)(k^{2}+{k^{\prime}}^{2}t^{2})}}, if 1\leq x<\infty, \operatorname{arcsc}\left(x,k\right)=\int_{0}^{x}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt{(1+t ^{2})(1+{k^{\prime}}^{2}t^{2})}}, if -\infty<x<\infty, \operatorname{arcns}\left(x,k\right)=\int_{x}^{\infty}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt {(t^{2}-1)(t^{2}-k^{2})}}, if 1\leq x<\infty, \operatorname{arcds}\left(x,k\right)=\int_{x}^{\infty}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt {(t^{2}+k^{2})(t^{2}-{k^{\prime}}^{2})}}, if k^{\prime}\leq x<\infty, \operatorname{arccs}\left(x,k\right)=\int_{x}^{\infty}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt {(1+t^{2})(t^{2}+{k^{\prime}}^{2})}}, if -\infty<x<\infty.
The integrals (22.15.12)–(22.15.14) can be regarded asnormal forms for representing the inverse functions.
Other integrals, for example, \int_{x}^{b}\frac{\mathrm{d}t}{\sqrt{(a^{2}+t^{2})(b^{2}-t^{2})}} can be transformed into normal form by elementary change of variables.
Comprehensive treatments are given by Carlson (2005),Lawden (1989, pp. 52–55),Bowman (1953, Chapter IX), andErdélyi et al. (1953b, pp. 296–301).
For representations of the inverse functions as symmetric elliptic integrals see §19.25(v).
